justification: The authors state: "One measure that has been used to assess facilitated processing is how long it takes to read narrative passages with and without event boundaries."
The text notes that "people tend to dwell longer on transition frames, suggesting increased processing demands at boundaries."

topic_or_construct: accessibility of previous-event information in working memory
justification: It is reported that when a boundary separates encoding and test, "people recognize the probe more slowly and less accurately," indicating recognition speed and accuracy as the measures.

The review states that when sentences share a location (same event) "they are faster to recognize the sentences that share a common location compared to sentences that do not," using recognition speed as the metric.

In the DuBrow & Davachi studies, "Recency judgments between two studied items were less accurate when the intervening sequence contained boundaries," showing that accuracy of recency judgments gauges temporal order memory.
